titleStmt.title: The Danes plot discovered against this kingdome. With the meeting of Van Trump Dutch admirall at sea with them, upon the English coast neer Hull: wherein is related their battell, flight, and apprehension of two of their ships at Plympton Maries, in the county of Devond. Which was sent to the Lord Burrowes, and divers other the peers now assembled in Parliament, by Sir Henry Waddam of the said county, and by him ordered to be printed. As also an order sent out by the Honourable Court of Parliament, for consummating of the state affairs. John Brovvn, Cler. Parliament.
titleStmt.author: Waddam, Henry, Sir.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE DANES PLOT DISCOVERED AGAINST THIS KINGDOME.

WITH, The meeting of Van Trump Dutch Admirall at Sea with them, upon the Engli≈øh Coa≈øt neer Hull: Wherein is related their Battell, flight, and apprehen≈øion of two of their ≈øhips at Plympton Maries, in the County of Devond.
Which was ≈øent to the Lord Burrowes, and divers other the Peers now a≈ø≈øembled in Parliament, by Sir Henry Waddam of the ≈øaid County, and by him Ordered to be Printed.
As al≈øo an Order ≈øent out by the Honourable Court of Parliament, for con≈øummating of the State Affairs.
London, Printed for Andrew Cor, and Marmaduke Boat, 1642

div.head: THE DANES PLOT DISCOVERED, Again≈øt this Kingdome.

opener.salute: RIGHT HONOVRABLE, AND my thrice noble Lord‚ñ™

div.p:
I am ≈øorry to receive ≈øuch intelligence as is daily pre≈øented to my hands, concerning the pre≈øent di≈øturbances of the times: no peculiar or perticular part therin, but requires him that bears the badg of loyalty inclo≈øed in his bre≈øt, not only to commi≈øerate, but al≈øo to u≈øe all diligence that may be comprehended in the circuit of his mean abilities to remove the ≈øame; ≈øparing neither in indeavors to confi≈øcate tho≈øe errors, already grounded in the hearts of malignants, nor means to nouri≈øh proficients in their
good intentions, the State of this Kingdome now requires valour to defend it ≈øelf, Coun≈øell to maintain tho≈øe Heroick parts, and a head to incourage and reward good de≈øerts.

1. We were never more able, nor as I conceive never more willing (being magnanimous, and valorous per≈øons) this Kingdome may reply without boa≈øting, that they need not fear any private or forrai ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢ nemies, if but once united in a corre≈øpondency of agreement; and this corre≈øpondency being in larged but with an unanimous coherence of the prote≈øtant party, mu≈øt by the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the Almighty, the Father and Author of truth, prove invincible and victorious? What age, or what times formerly and already pa≈øt in Times Diurnall, could ever challenge to them≈øelves more abilities? What per≈øons can, though guided with the malicious ≈øpleen of Herefie, attract or draw le≈ø≈øe hopes of a victory over us then now. Were there but a removall of tho≈øe di≈øagreements, which cau≈øe a generall
≈øadne≈ø≈øe in his Maje≈øties Subjects.

2 When was a Land better coun≈øelled, if accepted: can there be better advi≈øe given, then what proceeds from a Parliament of both Lords and Commons, every motion therin, and by them moved, concerning the principall affairs of this State; and again≈øt whom no tainture of di≈øloyalty could be a≈ø≈øert, without ju≈øt grounds, as proceedings from the Ventrim and bowels of Europe: long do I (with a zealous affection to that A≈ø≈øembly) wi≈øh continuance of the≈øe ble≈ø≈øings afore≈øaid towards us, and an addition of the latter.

3 Being the return of that head to joynwith you, for whom we all mourn: This Land had never ≈øo much need of care to be taken in the ≈øetling of the Militia, and putting the Kingdome in a Po≈øture of defence, as now; as does quotidialiy appear by the infinite commontions at home, and ≈øundry in≈øurrections and peenicious attempts of our enemies abroad.

My Lord,
IF it may not ≈øeem any way offen≈øive to your honour, I ≈øhall pre≈øent one to you; which whether you have heard of formerly, or no, I cannot tell, concerning the Danes; who pre≈øumed ≈øo far upon his Maje≈øties Coa≈øts as to come within ten leagues of his Maje≈øties Port of Hull, affrighting the people there by their daily report, proceeding from their own mouths; that they were bound for Engand, to receive ≈øatisfaction for ≈øome wrongs done them. Wherupon the Rumor ≈øpreading aboad, through the≈øe their threats, intelligence was given to ≈øome of his Maje≈øties ≈øhips then at Sea, being The James, and the Rainbow, there being with them ≈øix Merchants ≈øhips; who re≈øolved to go and meet them, therby to enquire the truth of this report: But ere they came neer, they perceived a ≈ømall Company of Dutch ≈øhips, men of war, ready provided for an encounter with the Danes; which gave them occa≈øion of beholding the pro≈øpect, they
begun the encounter about twelve of the clock on monday la≈øt, being the 21. of March, continuing fight for the ≈øpace of two hours very hotly, Van Trumpt the Dutch Admirall being then pre≈øent, behaved him≈øelf very valiantly: in≈øomuch that they ≈øunk many of the Danes ≈øhips, ere it was two of the clock; when having ≈øpent much powder and ≈øhot of either Party, they re≈øolved upon parly, which continued for an hour; wherein Van Trump de≈øired the peru≈øall of their Commi≈ø≈øion, and to know whether they were bound, the ground of their intents; which being denied, they fell to it again, and continued till it was dark: when taking the opportunity of the night, being very Cloudy, they fled; but the wind being contrary, ≈øome were driven upon the We≈øtern Coa≈øts of Dor≈øet and Devon≈øhire; Wheras two of them are apprehended at Plympton Maries in Devon≈øhire, untill the Owners ≈øhall be examined. When I ≈øhall give your honour real intelligence concerning their profe≈ø≈øion,
if ≈øo be they are not ≈øent up to London to tho≈øe other Rebels; And in the mean time, I ≈øhall re≈øt,

closer.signed: Your Honours obliged Servant, HENRY WADDAM.

div.p: IT is Ordered by the Honourable, and high Court of Parliament, that there be a ≈øpeedie cour≈øe taken for giving up the account of the ≈øeverall Counties in England and Wales, that have taken the Prote≈øtation of formerly ≈øet down, and giving in the Names of ≈øuch as ≈øhall refu≈øe it, that that bu≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e≈ø≈øe may be perfected; as al≈øo the account of Pol-money be likewi≈øe delivered up with all expedition, that by it and the la≈øt four Sub≈øidies, the Officers and Souldiers entertained for the Iri≈øh affairs, may bee ≈øent ever.
